title: States of the German Confederation
text:
The states of the German Confederation were member states of the <a href="German%20Confederation">German Confederation</a> lasted from 20 June 1815 until 24 August 1866.
On the whole, its territory nearly coincided with that remaining in the <a href="Holy%20Roman%20Empire">Holy Roman Empire</a> at the outbreak of the <a href="French%20Revolution">French Revolution</a>, with the notable exception of Belgium. Except for the two rival major powers, <a href="Austrian%20Empire">Austria</a> and <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Prussia">Prussia</a>, and the western left bank of the Rhine (which France had annexed, with tiny <a href="County%20of%20Katzenelnbogen">Katzenelnbogen</a>), the other member states (or their precursors) had been within <a href="Napoleon">Napoleon's</a> <a href="Confederation%20of%20the%20Rhine">Confederation of the Rhine</a>. 
The four free cities were <a href="republic">republic</a>s by constitution, while all the others were monarchies, some <a href="constitutional%20monarchy">constitutional</a> and some <a href="absolute%20monarchy">absolutist</a>.
The <a href="Duchy%20of%20Schleswig">Duchy of Schleswig</a> was never a member state. But Schleswig was traditionally connected to the duchies of Holstein and Lauenburg, which were member states. In 1848-51 (during the <a href="First%20Schleswig%20War">First Schleswig War</a>), it was treated by the German states and the short-lived <a href="German%20Empire%20%281848%E2%80%931849%29">German Empire</a> as a kind of member. In 1864, the Danish king transferred the three duchies to Austria and Prussia (after the <a href="Second%20Schleswig%20War">Second Schleswig War</a>.
